snp4.16:1.4.eng: about a teacher of such graceful speech,

snp4.16:1.5.eng: come from Tusita heaven to lead a community.

snp4.16:2.1.eng: To all the world with its gods

snp4.16:2.2.eng: he appears as a Clear-eyed One

snp4.16:3.1.eng: On behalf of the many here still bound,

snp4.16:3.2.eng: I have come seeking with a question

snp4.16:3.3.eng: to that Buddha, unattached and impartial,

snp4.16:3.4.eng: free of deceit, come to lead a community.

snp4.16:4.1.eng: Suppose a mendicant who loathes attachment

snp4.16:4.3.eng: the root of a tree, a charnel ground,

snp4.16:5.3.eng: at which a mendicant in their silent lodging

snp4.16:5.4.comm: Usually nigghosa means “message, noise”, but here it is glossed in Niddesa with the opposite meaning, appasadde appanigghose.

snp4.16:6.1.eng: On their journey to the untrodden place,

snp4.16:6.2.eng: how many adversities are there in the world

snp4.16:7.1.eng: What ways of speech should they have?

snp4.16:7.2.eng: Of what kind is their alms resort?

snp4.16:8.3.eng: would they purge their own stains,

snp4.16:9.1.eng: “If one who loathes attachment <j>frequents a lonely lodging,”

snp4.16:9.3.eng: “in their search for awakening—<j>as accords with the teaching—

snp4.16:9.4.eng: I shall tell you, as I understand it,

snp4.16:10.1.eng: An attentive one, a mindful mendicant <j>living on the periphery

snp4.16:10.2.eng: should not be afraid of five perils:
snp4.16:10.2.comm: Pariyantacārī is read by Niddesa, and followed by Bodhi, Norman, and Ñāṇadīpa, as “of bounded conduct”. However at DN 25:5.5 it means “living on the periphery”, which agrees with the current theme of the mendicant living remotely.

snp4.16:11.1.eng: Nor should they fear followers of other teachings,

snp4.16:11.2.eng: even having seen the many threats they pose.

snp4.16:11.3.eng: And then one seeking the good

snp4.16:12.2.eng: they should endure cold and excessive heat.

snp4.16:12.3.eng: Though afflicted by many such things, <j>the homeless one

snp4.16:13.1.pli: Theyyaṃ na kāre na musā bhaṇeyya,
snp4.16:13.1.eng: They must not steal or lie;

snp4.16:13.2.eng: and should touch creatures firm or frail with love.

snp4.16:13.3.eng: If they notice any clouding of the mind,

snp4.16:13.4.eng: they should dispel it as Māra’s ally.

snp4.16:14.1.eng: They must not fall under the sway <j>of anger or arrogance;

snp4.16:14.2.eng: having dug them out by the root, <j>they would stand firm.

snp4.16:14.3.eng: Then, faced with likes and dislikes,

snp4.16:15.1.eng: Putting wisdom in the foremost place, <j>rejoicing in goodness,

snp4.16:15.2.eng: they would put an end to those adversities.

snp4.16:15.3.eng: They’d vanquish discontent in their remote lodging.

snp4.16:15.4.eng: And they’d vanquish the four lamentations:

snp4.16:16.1.eng: ‘What will I eat? Where will I eat?

snp4.16:16.2.eng: Oh, I slept badly! Where will I sleep?’

snp4.16:16.3.eng: The trainee, the migrant without abode,

snp4.16:17.1.eng: Receiving food and clothes in due season,

snp4.16:17.2.eng: they would know moderation <j>for the sake of contentment.

snp4.16:17.3.eng: Guarded in these things, <j>walking restrained in the village,

snp4.16:17.4.eng: they wouldn’t speak harshly even when provoked.

snp4.16:18.2.eng: devoted to absorption, they’d be very wakeful.

snp4.16:18.4.eng: they should cut off worrisome habits of thought.

snp4.16:19.1.eng: A mindful one would welcome reproach,

snp4.16:19.2.eng: and would dissolve hard-heartedness <j>toward their spiritual companions.

snp4.16:19.3.eng: They may utter skillful speech, but not for too long,

snp4.16:19.4.eng: and they shouldn’t provoke people to blame.

snp4.16:20.1.eng: And there are five more taints in the world,

snp4.16:20.2.eng: for the removal of which <j>the mindful one should train,

snp4.16:21.1.eng: Having removed desire for these things,
snp4.16:21.1.comm: Vineyya here is absolutive, not optative.

snp4.16:21.2.eng: a mindful mendicant, their heart well freed,

snp4.16:21.3.eng: rightly investigating the Dhamma in good time,
snp4.16:21.3.comm: I think the force of kālena here is not, “at the right time” (when is the wrong time?) but “before it’s too late”.

snp4.16:21.4.eng: at one, would banish the darkness.”

snp4.2:1.1.eng: Trapped in a cave, thickly overspread,

snp4.2:1.3.eng: That sort is far from seclusion,

snp4.2:1.4.pli: Kāmā hi loke na hi suppahāyā.
snp4.2:1.4.eng: for sensual pleasures in the world <j>are not easy to give up.

snp4.2:2.1.eng: The chains of desire, the bonds of life’s pleasures

snp4.2:2.2.eng: are hard to escape, for one cannot free another.
snp4.2:2.2.comm: Te duppamuñca has been taken by most translators as referring to people, in senses either active (Bodhi’s “let go with difficulty”) or passive (Norman’s “are hard to release”). However the phrase occurs in a very similar context at SN 3.10:5.2 and Dhp 346:2, where it refers to the chains that are hard to escape.

snp4.2:2.3.eng: Looking to the past or the future,

snp4.2:2.4.pli: Ime va kāme purime va jappaṃ.
snp4.2:2.4.eng: they pray for these pleasures or former ones.
snp4.2:2.4.comm: Jappa means both to “incant” and to “long for”, and the English “pray’ has exactly the same connotations—for exactly the same reasons. They originated in begging favors of a god.

snp4.2:3.1.eng: Greedy, fixated, infatuated by sensual pleasures,

snp4.2:3.3.eng: When led to suffering they lament,

snp4.2:3.4.eng: “What will become of us <j>when we pass away from here?”

snp4.2:4.1.eng: That’s why a personage should train in this life:

snp4.2:4.2.eng: should you know that anything in the world is wrong,

snp4.2:4.3.eng: don’t act wrongly on account of that;

snp4.2:4.4.eng: for the attentive say this life is short.

snp4.2:5.1.eng: I see the world’s population floundering,

snp4.2:5.2.eng: given to craving for future lives.

snp4.2:5.3.eng: Base men wail in the jaws of death,
snp4.2:5.3.comm: “Jaws of death” (maccumukha) is also at SN 2.22:7.3. Compare Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.1.1, “he escapes from the jaws of death” (tanmṛtyumukhātpramucyate).

snp4.2:5.4.eng: not rid of craving for life after life.

snp4.2:6.2.eng: like fish in puddles of a dried-up stream.

snp4.2:6.4.eng: forming no attachment to future lives.

snp4.2:7.1.eng: Rid of desire for both ends,
snp4.2:7.1.comm: The reference here is to the two ends of contact (AN 6.61) rather than the two extremes of views or paths.

snp4.2:7.2.eng: having completely understood contact, free of greed,

snp4.2:7.3.eng: doing nothing for which they’d blame themselves,

snp4.2:7.4.eng: the attentive don’t cling to the seen and the heard.

snp4.2:8.1.eng: Having completely understood perception <j>and having crossed the flood,
snp4.2:8.1.comm: Bodhi, Norman, and Ñāṇadīpa, apparently following the commentary, take vitareyya as an optative. But the previous verse spoke of an arahant, and here the one who has fully understood perception must have already crossed over. Vitareyya oghaṁ occurs at Snp 3.5:13.2, where vitareyya is clearly an absolutive, and is rendered as such by both Bodhi and Norman.

snp4.2:8.2.eng: the sage, not clinging to possessions,

snp4.2:8.3.eng: with dart plucked out, living diligently,

snp4.2:8.4.eng: does not hope for this world or the next.

snp4.3:1.1.comm: Duṭṭhamana, or more commonly paduṭṭhamana, means “malice” not “corruption”, as is found through the suttas and confirmed by the Niddesa.

snp4.3:1.2.eng: while others speak set on truth.

snp4.3:1.3.eng: When disputes come up a sage does not get involved,

snp4.3:1.4.eng: which is why they’ve no barrenness at all.

snp4.3:2.1.eng: How can you transcend your own view

snp4.3:2.2.eng: when you’re led by preference, dogmatic in belief?
snp4.3:2.2.comm: Bodhi, Norman, and Ñāṇadīpa all render chanda as “desire”, and that is certainly the sense of chandānunīto at SN 35.94:6.4. Here, however, Niddesa glosses with synonyms for “view” and this seems like a more plausible sense. Note too the sense of niviṭṭha as “dogmatic”, which recurs through the Aṭṭhakavagga (cp. abhinivesa).

snp4.3:2.3.comm: Samattāni is regularly used of vows “undertaken”, and given the following verse this is surely the meaning here, contra Niddesa and commentary. See Snp 4.4:5.1, where samādāya is used in the same sense.

snp4.3:2.4.eng: you’d speak according to your notion.
snp4.3:2.4.comm: Here we find a sense of jānāti that doesn’t fit the English idea of “knowledge” as “true belief”. The idea is that they speak from their own (limited and opinionated) ideas. It’s not as pejorative as “opinion” nor as solid as “knowledge”, so I render as “notion”. We find this usage commonly in the final two chapters of Snp.

snp4.3:3.2.eng: of their own precepts and vows.

snp4.3:3.3.eng: They have an ignoble nature, <j>say those who are skilled,

snp4.3:3.4.eng: since they speak on themselves of their own accord.

snp4.3:4.2.eng: never boasts “thus am I” of their precepts.

snp4.3:4.3.eng: They have a noble nature, say those who are skilled,

snp4.3:4.4.eng: who have no pretensions about anything in the world.
snp4.3:4.4.comm: Ussada, here rendered “pretension”, is a poetic term with the literal sense of “swelling”. In this chapter it has a close connection with “pride” (Snp 4.10:8.4, Snp 4.14:6.4; cf. the English sense of pride as “protuberance”), although this connection is less obvious elsewhere (Snp 3.6:14.4, Iti 97:8.4, and Ud 1.4:2.1 = Kd 1:2.3.6). Its absence is a sign of a true brahmin (MN 98:11.19, Dhp 400:2, Snp 3.9:36.1). The Niddesa does not link it with pride especially, rather explaining it as sevenfold: greed, hate, delusion, conceit, views, corruptions, and deeds (Mnd 10:105.4).

snp4.3:5.1.eng: For one who formulates and creates teachings,

snp4.3:5.2.eng: and promotes them despite their defects,

snp4.3:5.3.eng: if they see an advantage for themselves,

snp4.3:5.4.eng: they become dependent on that, <j>relying on unstable peace.

snp4.3:6.1.eng: It’s not easy to get over dogmatic views

snp4.3:6.2.eng: adopted after judging among the teachings.

snp4.3:6.3.eng: That’s why, among all these dogmas, a person

snp4.3:6.4.eng: ditches one teaching and takes up another.

snp4.3:7.1.eng: The cleansed one has no formulated view

snp4.3:7.2.eng: at all in the world about the different realms.

snp4.3:7.3.eng: Having given up illusion and conceit,

snp4.3:7.4.eng: by what path would they go? They are not involved.

snp4.3:8.1.eng: For one who gets involved is embroiled in disputes about teachings—

snp4.3:8.2.eng: but how to dispute with the uninvolved? <j>About what?

snp4.3:8.3.pli: Attā nirattā na hi tassa atthi,
snp4.3:8.3.eng: For picking up and putting down <j>is not what they do;
snp4.3:8.3.comm: The problem addressed is one who is picking up one thing after another. It’s therefore best to translate atta in an active sense, per Niddesa: gahaṇaṁ muñcanā samatikkanto.We find similar phrases describing the living arahant in such prose passages as SN 22.79:14.1.

snp4.3:8.4.eng: they have shaken off all views in this very life.

snp4.4:1.1.comm: The sight of saint or holy person was believed to grant blessings (see AN 6.30, MN 81:6.5, Snp 2.4:10.2). As Bodhi remarks, aroga (“healthy”) refers to the “self”, which is frequently described as the subtle body that survives death (DN 1:2.38.3: rūpī attā hoti arogo). Here, however, what is “seen” is the soul as a physical body manifesting purity and wellness, as in the case of Māgaṇḍiya (MN 75:19.15).

snp4.4:1.2.eng: it is vision that grants a person purity.”

snp4.4:1.3.eng: Recalling this notion of the ultimate,
snp4.4:1.3.comm: Here as in Snp 4.3, ñāṇa is used in the sense of “notion”. Bodhi, Norman, and Ñāṇadīpa all follow Niddesa in taking abhijāna in its usual sense of “understanding, direct knowing”. But here the secondary sense of “recall” fits better. Someone thinking about their vision of a holy man believes that there must be an observer of such purity, i.e. a self.

snp4.4:1.4.eng: they believe in the notion <j>that there is one who observes purity.
snp4.4:1.4.comm: Pacceti is a standard verb for someone who “believes” in a religious rite or idea.

snp4.4:2.1.eng: If a person were granted purity through what is seen,

snp4.4:2.2.eng: or if by a notion they could give up suffering,

snp4.4:2.3.eng: then one with attachments is purified by another:

snp4.4:2.4.pli: Diṭṭhī hi naṃ pāva tathā vadānaṃ.
snp4.4:2.4.eng: their view betrays them as one who asserts thus.

snp4.4:3.1.eng: The brahmin speaks not of purity from another

snp4.4:3.2.eng: in terms of what has been seen, heard, or thought; <j>or by precepts or vows.

snp4.4:3.3.eng: They are unsullied in the midst of good and evil,

snp4.4:3.4.eng: letting go what was picked up, <j>without creating anything new here.

snp4.4:4.1.eng: Having let go the last they lay hold of the next;

snp4.4:4.2.eng: following impulse, they don’t pass the chain.

snp4.4:4.3.eng: They grab on and let loose like a monkey

snp4.4:4.4.comm: The monkey grabs the branches, not the trunk, as a metaphor for missing the essence. And to drive home the pun, religious orders are called “branches”.

snp4.4:5.1.eng: Having undertaken their own vows, a personage

snp4.4:5.2.eng: visits various teachers, <j>being attached to perception.
snp4.4:5.2.comm: See uccāvacaṁ vā pana dassanāya gacchati at AN 6.30:2.2. In the current poem, it refers to someone who visits a variety of teachers or sects, as per Niddesa.

snp4.4:5.3.eng: One who knows, having comprehended the truth <j>through the knowledges,
snp4.4:5.3.comm: Here the plural vedehi stands for the tevijjā.

snp4.4:5.4.eng: does not visit various teachers, being of vast wisdom.

snp4.4:6.1.eng: They are remote from all things

snp4.4:6.2.pli: Yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vā;

snp4.4:6.4.eng: how could anyone in this world judge them?

snp4.4:7.1.eng: They don’t make things up or promote them,

snp4.4:7.2.eng: or speak of the uttermost purity.

snp4.4:7.3.eng: After untying the tight knot of grasping

snp4.4:7.4.eng: they long for nothing in the world.

snp4.4:8.1.eng: The brahmin has stepped over the perimeter;

snp4.4:8.2.eng: knowing and seeing, they adopt nothing.
snp4.4:8.2.comm: Note that samuggahīta is used here in the same sense as Snp 4.3:6.2 or Snp 2.12:11.1, i.e. the “adoption” of a theory or view.

snp4.4:8.3.eng: Neither in love with passion <j>nor besotted by dispassion,

snp4.4:8.4.eng: there is nothing here they adopt as the ultimate.

snp4.5:1.1.eng: If, maintaining that theirs is the “ultimate” view,

snp4.5:1.2.eng: a personage makes it out to be highest in the world;
snp4.5:1.2.comm: Reading yad- here and below as yadi.

snp4.5:1.3.eng: then they declare all others are “lesser”;

snp4.5:1.4.eng: that’s why they’re not beyond disputes.

snp4.5:2.1.eng: If they see an advantage for themselves

snp4.5:2.2.eng: in what’s seen, heard, or thought; <j>or in precepts or vows,

snp4.5:2.3.eng: in that case, having adopted that one alone,

snp4.5:2.4.eng: they see all others as inferior.

snp4.5:3.1.eng: Those who are skilled say that, too, is a knot,

snp4.5:3.2.eng: relying on which people see others as lesser.

snp4.5:3.3.pli: Tasmā hi diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vā,
snp4.5:3.3.eng: That’s why a mendicant ought not rely

snp4.5:3.4.eng: on what’s seen, heard, or thought, <j>or on precepts and vows.

snp4.5:4.1.eng: Nor would they form a view about the world

snp4.5:4.2.eng: through a notion or through precepts and vows.

snp4.5:4.3.eng: They would never represent themselves as “equal”,

snp4.5:5.1.eng: What was picked up has been set down <j>and is not grasped again;

snp4.5:5.2.eng: they form no dependency even on notions.

snp4.5:5.3.eng: They follow no side among the factions,

snp4.5:5.4.eng: and believe in no view at all.

snp4.5:6.1.eng: One here who has no wish for either end—

snp4.5:6.2.eng: for any state of existence in this life or the next—

snp4.5:6.3.eng: has adopted no dogma at all

snp4.5:7.1.pli: Tassīdha diṭṭhe va sute mute vā,
snp4.5:7.1.eng: For them not even the tiniest idea is formulated here

snp4.5:7.2.eng: regarding what is seen, heard, or thought.

snp4.5:7.3.eng: That brahmin does not grasp any view—

snp4.5:7.4.eng: how could anyone in this world judge them?

snp4.5:8.1.eng: They don’t make things up or promote them,

snp4.5:8.2.eng: and don’t subscribe to any of the doctrines.

snp4.5:8.3.eng: The brahmin has no need to be led by precept or vow;

snp4.5:8.4.eng: gone to the far shore, one such does not return.
